problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized as objective
Assignment of each item to a box index
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box boundaries
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].y >= 0

fit_items_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlap in x-axis
                x_non_overlap: bool = (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x
                )
                # Check for non-overlap in y-axis
                y_non_overlap: bool = (
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )
                # Assert that at least one axis has non-overlap (i.e., no overlap)
                assert x_non_overlap or y_non_overlap

no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_consistency(
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    # Each item must be assigned to exactly one box (already ensured by domain of assignments)
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= 20

ensure_item_assignment_consistency(item_box_assignments)

# Object type for items with width and height
Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=100),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=100)
})

# Object type for position (x, y) of an item within a box
Position = DSRecord({
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=100),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=100)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT: int = 100
BOX_WIDTH: int = 100
ITEMS: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item) = [
    {"width": 96, "height": 98},
    {"width": 8, "height": 78},
    {"width": 9, "height": 46},
    {"width": 91, "height": 99},
    {"width": 74, "height": 71},
    {"width": 52, "height": 82},
    {"width": 93, "height": 75},
    {"width": 91, "height": 68},
    {"width": 15, "height": 7},
    {"width": 58, "height": 58},
    {"width": 90, "height": 66},
    {"width": 4, "height": 66},
    {"width": 67, "height": 53},
    {"width": 76, "height": 96},
    {"width": 98, "height": 69},
    {"width": 77, "height": 94},
    {"width": 81, "height": 62},
    {"width": 55, "height": 95},
    {"width": 67, "height": 84},
    {"width": 61, "height": 99}
]
N_ITEMS: int = 20
nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)
item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
N_ITEMS : int = 20
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 20
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 20


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=20):
    max_box: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS + 1):
        if assignments[i] > max_box:
            max_box = assignments[i]
    return max_box

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.

    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap
                # Not overlapping if one is to the left of the other
                # Or one is above the other
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

):

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),

):

            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping conditions
                # Either i is to the right of j

                # Or i is above j

                    positions[i].x >= positions[j].x + items[j].width or

# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
                        nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)):
    # Objective is to minimize the number of boxes used
    max_box_used = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if item_box_assignments[i] > max_box_used:
            max_box_used = item_box_assignments[i]
    return max_box_used

# Ensure all items are assigned to a box

    assert item_box_assignments[i] >= 1
    assert item_box_assignments[i] <= 20

        max_assigned_box = item_box_assignments[i]

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping conditions
                # If any of these is true, there's no overlap:
                # - i is to the right of j
                # - i is to the left of j
                # - i is above j
                # - i is below j
                assert (positions[i].x >= positions[j].x + items[j].width or 
                        positions[j].x >= positions[i].x + items[i].width or

        assert item_box_assignments[i] <= 20

# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
                        nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)):
    # Objective is to minimize the number of boxes used
    max_box_used = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if item_box_assignments[i] > max_box_used:
            max_box_used = item_box_assignments[i]
    return max_box_used

# Ensure all items are assigned to a box
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert item_box_assignments[i] >= 1
    assert item_box_assignments[i] <= 20

# Ensure nr_used_boxes reflects the actual number of boxes used
max_assigned_box = 0
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    if item_box_assignments[i] > max_assigned_box:
        max_assigned_box = item_box_assignments[i]

assert nr_used_boxes == max_assigned_box

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments, nr_used_boxes)
minimize(objective)

    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Get the assigned box and position for the item
        box_id: int = assignments[i]
        pos: Position = positions[i]
        item: Item = items[i]
        
        # Ensure the item fits within the box boundaries
        assert pos.x + item.width <= box_width
        assert pos.y + item.height <= box_height
        assert pos.x >= 0
        assert pos.y >= 0

ensure_items_fit_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def ensure_no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping conditions
                # If any of these is true, there's no overlap:
                # - i is to the right of j
                # - i is to the left of j
                # - i is above j
                # - i is below j
                assert (positions[i].x >= positions[j].x + items[j].width or 
                        positions[j].x >= positions[i].x + items[i].width or 
                        positions[i].y >= positions[j].y + items[j].height or 
                        positions[j].y >= positions[i].y + items[i].height)

ensure_no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_and_position_uniqueness(
    item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
):
    # This function ensures each item has a unique assignment and position.
    # Since the problem states one item can be exactly in one box,
    # and we're assigning positions, this is implicitly handled by the structure.
    # However, we assert that every item has a valid box assignment and position.
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Each item must be assigned to a box between 1 and 20
        assert item_box_assignments[i] >= 1
        assert item_box_assignments[i] <= 20
        
        # Positions are already bounded by their type definition
        # x_y_positions[i].x >= 0 and <= 100
        # x_y_positions[i].y >= 0 and <= 100

ensure_item_assignment_and_position_uniqueness(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, to be minimized
Assignment of each item to a box index
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position (x, y) of each item within its assigned box
